flow.descriptionCdata:
5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.041129d6-e49b-44b6-80b5-dfc79cf09453.prompt=A chef server user name with sufficient rights 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.077bc288-fc18-47be-8ec2-de9e30ef6d16.prompt=Enter a value for responseTimeOut 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.0cde0aba-71df-48d6-ba63-fd77cc5c9a83.prompt=Enter a value for responseTimeOut 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.15e08632-b81f-4eae-a835-37e7e4afe9e3.prompt=Enter a value for apiHostPassword 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.16cc8ddd-6027-4f05-896d-7e8d89ef0dc4.prompt=Enter a value for array 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.18ef13d4-5666-4a99-9843-69b64af4f526.description=
Writes the data from "contents" input to the requested file. The operation can be used to overwrite existing content of the file,  append extra lines to it or even create a new file.

Input Parameters\:
source           -  Full path to file. If the file does not exist it is created first.
contents        - The contents to write to the file. Contents can have a new line delimiter which is also given as input to the operation, but it is optional. Example\: "This is line no. 01\nThis is line no. 2\n" where \n is the delimiter.
delimiter         - Specifies the newline delimiter (\n, \r\n, etc) that is used for the "contents" input.
characterSet  - The character encoding used to write to the file. The default is UTF-8. Example values\: windows-1252, UTF-16, UTF-16BE,  ISO-8859-1, US-ASCII, Shift_JIS etc.
overwrite       - Specifies whether to overwrite the file or append to it. By default, the used value is true. Accepted values\: true, false or the empty string. If this is left empty, the file will be overwritten.

Responses\:
success - file/directory is written successfully
failure   - unable to write to file/directory
\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\# 
Writes the data from "contents" input to the requested file. The operation can be used to overwrite existing content of the file,  append extra lines to it or even create a new file.

Input Parameters\:
source           -  Full path to file. If the file does not exist it is created first.
contents        - The contents to write to the file. Contents can have a new line delimiter which is also given as input to the operation, but it is optional. Example\: "This is line no. 01\nThis is line no. 2\n" where \n is the delimiter.
delimiter         - Specifies the newline delimiter (\n, \r\n, etc) that is used for the "contents" input.
characterSet  - The character encoding used to write to the file. The default is UTF-8. Example values\: windows-1252, UTF-16, UTF-16BE,  ISO-8859-1, US-ASCII, Shift_JIS etc.
overwrite       - Specifies whether to overwrite the file or append to it. By default, the used value is true. Accepted values\: true, false or the empty string. If this is left empty, the file will be overwritten.

Responses\:
success - file/directory is written successfully
failure   - unable to write to file/directory
5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.195311d2-2725-4f5a-8075-dc43c0e5d9c0.prompt=Enter a value for apiHostPassword 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.1fa3a527-3e68-4014-972f-37f1ad210985.prompt=Enter a value for apiHostRepo 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.2817e26a-e1d6-4dba-b486-e9d6397cd112.description=
Inserts a new name/value property into a JSON object, where the value is a valid JSON string. If the  input is not a valid string representation of a JSON object, the operation fails.
The 'Add Property to Object' operation can be used to add a property with a simple string value. 

Examples\: 
1)
    Inputs\:
        jsonObject\: {}
        newPropertyName\: test
        newPropertyValue\: [1,2,3]
     Result\:
         { "test"\:[1,2,3]}
2)
    Inputs\:
        jsonObject\: {}
        newPropertyName\: test
        newPropertyValue\: {"a"\:"b"}
     Result\:
         { "test"\:{"a"\:"b"}}
3)
    Inputs\:
        jsonObject\: {}
        newPropertyName\: test
        newPropertyValue\: 1
     Result\:
         { "test"\:1}

Inputs\:
    jsonObject - String representation of a JSON object. Objects in JSON are a collection of name value pairs, separated by a colon and surrounded with curly brackets {}. The name must be a string value, and the value can be a single string or any valid JSON object or array.
Examples\: {"one"\:1, "two"\:2}, {"one"\:{"a"\:"a","B"\:"B"}, "two"\:"two", "three"\:[1,2,3.4]}
    newPropertyName - The name of the new property to add to the JSON object. 
Examples\: property1, some_property, another property
    newPropertyValue - The value for the new property. This must be a valid JSON representation of a JavaScript object.
Examples\: 1, {"A"\:"A"}, [1,2,3,4]

Results\:
    Result - The JSON array with the inserted element.

Responses\:
    success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
    failure - The operation completed unsuccessfully. See the message in  for details.
5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.29a53d2b-46cb-4b7a-be10-14da9ae77bee.callout=Prepare the run_list value 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.2c04c421-dfdf-415b-b030-b5e3b606802c.prompt=Enter a value for cookbookName 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.312b89c7-0ae4-480e-aba5-0adafe28a647.description=\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#Additional Parameters\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\# This operation lists the defind roles. Inputs\: responseTimeOut - Time out for the operation, populates the OOB timeout variable. apiHostName - The name/fqdn of a host which runs Chefs APi client (knife). apiHostUser - A user name with sufficient rights to run the knife commands. apiHostPassword - The apiHostUser's password. apiHostRepo - The path to the chef repository (The chef-repo folder). outputFormat - The format of the result. You can use json\text\yaml\pp Outputs\: roleList - The list of roles, seperated by a "|" \#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#Original Description\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\# 
Uses WMI to attempt to create a remote process on a machine.  The command passed should be formatted as though it was run on the command line.

CAUTION\: internally 'cmd /c' gets prepended to the command passed.  Also '2>tempfile 1>tempfile' get appended to the command so that we can attempt to capture stdout and stderr.
So your command will look like this when executed\:
	'cmd /c [yourcommand] 2>temperr 1>tempout'

Inputs\:
    host - Hostname or ip address of the target machine.
    command - The command you want executed. Special characters\: <, >, (, ), & need to be escaped using the caret (^) character.  The only exception to this rule is when the > character is used to redirect output.
    user - Username to use for remote WMI impersonation and thread impersonation on the RAS host for this operation (can be left blank).
    password - Password of the user.
    outputPath - Network accessible path used by the operation to store temporary files. If not specified it points to \\host\admin$\temp\'. If this path is not accessible you should change it to use another share that the host local system account has write access to. By default the path will have to be changed on Windows 2000 systems.
    currentDirectory - Current directory.
    characterSet - The character encoding used to write the batch file that will be remotely executed by the operation. Unicode character encodings may not supported for this input (utf-8, utf-16, etc.).  Support for unicode encodings depends on target system capabilities.  By default this encoding will also be used to read the command output that is redirected to temporary files.  If the command output is expected to be of different encoding, specify the different encoding in the outputCharacterSet input.  Default value\: The encoding of the operating system where is RAS installed.
Examples\: ibm437, shift_jis
    outputCharacterSet - The character encoding used to read the command output that was redirected to temporary files.  Only need to specify this input if the output of the command is known to output a different character encoding.  As an example\: the 'wmic' command returns utf-16 encoded output.
Examples\: ibm437, shift_jis, utf-8, utf-16
    timeout - The number of seconds before assuming the remote process is no longer functional. After the timeout has expired the remote process and all child processes will be terminated.
Default value\: 90

Responses\:
    success - Remote process successfully launched and has completed executing.
    failure - Unable to start remote process.

Results\:
    returnResult - Return value from WMI for starting the process (not the exit value of the process).
    processID - The process id of the remote process.
    processReturnCode - The return code of the remote process.
    stdOut - Standard output from the remote process.
    stdErr - Standard error from the remote process.

Notes\: 
List of possible encoding names (Support for the encoding may depend on the version or language of the RAS OS)\:

Encoding Name\:	Description\:
IBM437		OEM United States
DOS-720		Arabic (DOS)
ibm737		Greek (DOS)
ibm775		Baltic (DOS)
ibm850		Western European (DOS)
ibm852		Central European (DOS)
IBM855		OEM Cyrillic
ibm857		Turkish (DOS)
IBM00858		OEM Multilingual Latin I
IBM860		Portuguese (DOS)
ibm861		Icelandic (DOS)
DOS-862		Hebrew (DOS)
IBM863		French Canadian (DOS)
IBM864		Arabic (864)
IBM865		Nordic (DOS)
cp866		Cyrillic (DOS)
ibm869		Greek, Modern (DOS)
shift_jis		Japanese (Shift-JIS)
gb2312		Chinese Simplified (GB2312)
ks_c_5601-1987	Korean
big5		Chinese Traditional (Big5)
utf-16		Unicode
unicodeFFFE		Unicode (Big-Endian)
utf-7		Unicode (UTF-7)
utf-8		Unicode (UTF-8)
utf-32		Unicode (UTF-32)
utf-32BE		Unicode (UTF-32 Big-Endian)
Johab		Korean (Johab)
us-ascii		US-ASCII
koi8-r		Cyrillic (KOI8-R)
euc-jp		Japanese (EUC)
EUC-CN		Chinese Simplified (EUC)
euc-kr		Korean (EUC)
hz-gb-2312		Chinese Simplified (HZ)
GB18030		Chinese Simplified (GB18030)
5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.34dbb647-4316-4d3e-86dd-bcd16798bd5d.description=\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#Additional Parameters\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\# This operation creates or updates a role from a file. Inputs\: roleName - The role name. responseTimeOut - Time out for the operation, populates the OOB timeout variable. apiHostName - The name/fqdn of a host which runs Chefs APi client (knife). apiHostUser - A user name with sufficient rights to run the knife commands. apiHostPassword - The apiHostUser's password. apiHostRepo - The path to the chef repository (The chef-repo folder). Notes\: - In case the role exists, it will be updated with no warning\! - The operations aasumes that the file is located under chef-repo\roles and that the file name is the role's name with the "json" extention \#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#Original Description\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\# 
Uses WMI to attempt to create a remote process on a machine.  The command passed should be formatted as though it was run on the command line.

CAUTION\: internally 'cmd /c' gets prepended to the command passed.  Also '2>tempfile 1>tempfile' get appended to the command so that we can attempt to capture stdout and stderr.
So your command will look like this when executed\:
	'cmd /c [yourcommand] 2>temperr 1>tempout'

Inputs\:
    host - Hostname or ip address of the target machine.
    command - The command you want executed. Special characters\: <, >, (, ), & need to be escaped using the caret (^) character.  The only exception to this rule is when the > character is used to redirect output.
    user - Username to use for remote WMI impersonation and thread impersonation on the RAS host for this operation (can be left blank).
    password - Password of the user.
    outputPath - Network accessible path used by the operation to store temporary files. If not specified it points to \\host\admin$\temp\'. If this path is not accessible you should change it to use another share that the host local system account has write access to. By default the path will have to be changed on Windows 2000 systems.
    currentDirectory - Current directory.
    characterSet - The character encoding used to write the batch file that will be remotely executed by the operation. Unicode character encodings may not supported for this input (utf-8, utf-16, etc.).  Support for unicode encodings depends on target system capabilities.  By default this encoding will also be used to read the command output that is redirected to temporary files.  If the command output is expected to be of different encoding, specify the different encoding in the outputCharacterSet input.  Default value\: The encoding of the operating system where is RAS installed.
Examples\: ibm437, shift_jis
    outputCharacterSet - The character encoding used to read the command output that was redirected to temporary files.  Only need to specify this input if the output of the command is known to output a different character encoding.  As an example\: the 'wmic' command returns utf-16 encoded output.
Examples\: ibm437, shift_jis, utf-8, utf-16
    timeout - The number of seconds before assuming the remote process is no longer functional. After the timeout has expired the remote process and all child processes will be terminated.
Default value\: 90

Responses\:
    success - Remote process successfully launched and has completed executing.
    failure - Unable to start remote process.

Results\:
    returnResult - Return value from WMI for starting the process (not the exit value of the process).
    processID - The process id of the remote process.
    processReturnCode - The return code of the remote process.
    stdOut - Standard output from the remote process.
    stdErr - Standard error from the remote process.

Notes\: 
List of possible encoding names (Support for the encoding may depend on the version or language of the RAS OS)\:

Encoding Name\:	Description\:
IBM437		OEM United States
DOS-720		Arabic (DOS)
ibm737		Greek (DOS)
ibm775		Baltic (DOS)
ibm850		Western European (DOS)
ibm852		Central European (DOS)
IBM855		OEM Cyrillic
ibm857		Turkish (DOS)
IBM00858		OEM Multilingual Latin I
IBM860		Portuguese (DOS)
ibm861		Icelandic (DOS)
DOS-862		Hebrew (DOS)
IBM863		French Canadian (DOS)
IBM864		Arabic (864)
IBM865		Nordic (DOS)
cp866		Cyrillic (DOS)
ibm869		Greek, Modern (DOS)
shift_jis		Japanese (Shift-JIS)
gb2312		Chinese Simplified (GB2312)
ks_c_5601-1987	Korean
big5		Chinese Traditional (Big5)
utf-16		Unicode
unicodeFFFE		Unicode (Big-Endian)
utf-7		Unicode (UTF-7)
utf-8		Unicode (UTF-8)
utf-32		Unicode (UTF-32)
utf-32BE		Unicode (UTF-32 Big-Endian)
Johab		Korean (Johab)
us-ascii		US-ASCII
koi8-r		Cyrillic (KOI8-R)
euc-jp		Japanese (EUC)
EUC-CN		Chinese Simplified (EUC)
euc-kr		Korean (EUC)
hz-gb-2312		Chinese Simplified (HZ)
GB18030		Chinese Simplified (GB18030)
5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.38b82828-ea12-4701-9140-f39a14fce3b2.callout=Get Recepie 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.3b3656db-6c1c-4c92-870a-bfccd96acb70.prompt=Enter a value for apiHostPassword 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.40a94e36-8d24-423f-9753-110e2d7a078c.prompt=Enter a value for apiHostUser 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.4461b9fc-cbf7-4da3-887e-c36adee3ff63.callout=get the run_list array value and add the new recipe to the array 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.46dcf640-e150-4bfc-a432-dd8c743ec3f2.prompt=Enter a value for apiHostRepo 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.4bb6e507-e488-4bfa-96b6-08d3077f4505.prompt=Enter a value for apiHostName 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.4ceb7135-5b6e-43e0-9d68-5d0da532492f.prompt=Enter a value for apiHostUser 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.4ff91121-c395-4544-964a-cfe21fbe6a10.prompt=The path to the chef repository (The chef-repo folder). 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.52670461-7019-4d81-8ef2-9fae6bbcb187.prompt=Enter a value for roleName 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.5548a163-450a-4951-8adf-2ab04f20b45e.description=\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#Additional Parameters\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\# This operation lists the cookbooks which are deployd on the Chef server. Inputs\: responseTimeOut - Time out for the operation, populates the OOB timeout variable. apiHostName - The name/fqdn of a host which runs Chefs APi client (knife). apiHostUser - A user name with sufficient rights to run the knife commands. apiHostPassword - The apiHostUser's password. apiHostRepo - The path to the chef repository (The chef-repo folder). outputFormat - The format of the result. You can use json\text\yaml\pp Outputs\: cookbooks - the list of cookbooks. \#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#Original Description\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\# 
Uses WMI to attempt to create a remote process on a machine.  The command passed should be formatted as though it was run on the command line.

CAUTION\: internally 'cmd /c' gets prepended to the command passed.  Also '2>tempfile 1>tempfile' get appended to the command so that we can attempt to capture stdout and stderr.
So your command will look like this when executed\:
	'cmd /c [yourcommand] 2>temperr 1>tempout'

Inputs\:
    host - Hostname or ip address of the target machine.
    command - The command you want executed. Special characters\: <, >, (, ), & need to be escaped using the caret (^) character.  The only exception to this rule is when the > character is used to redirect output.
    user - Username to use for remote WMI impersonation and thread impersonation on the RAS host for this operation (can be left blank).
    password - Password of the user.
    outputPath - Network accessible path used by the operation to store temporary files. If not specified it points to \\host\admin$\temp\'. If this path is not accessible you should change it to use another share that the host local system account has write access to. By default the path will have to be changed on Windows 2000 systems.
    currentDirectory - Current directory.
    characterSet - The character encoding used to write the batch file that will be remotely executed by the operation. Unicode character encodings may not supported for this input (utf-8, utf-16, etc.).  Support for unicode encodings depends on target system capabilities.  By default this encoding will also be used to read the command output that is redirected to temporary files.  If the command output is expected to be of different encoding, specify the different encoding in the outputCharacterSet input.  Default value\: The encoding of the operating system where is RAS installed.
Examples\: ibm437, shift_jis
    outputCharacterSet - The character encoding used to read the command output that was redirected to temporary files.  Only need to specify this input if the output of the command is known to output a different character encoding.  As an example\: the 'wmic' command returns utf-16 encoded output.
Examples\: ibm437, shift_jis, utf-8, utf-16
    timeout - The number of seconds before assuming the remote process is no longer functional. After the timeout has expired the remote process and all child processes will be terminated.
Default value\: 90

Responses\:
    success - Remote process successfully launched and has completed executing.
    failure - Unable to start remote process.

Results\:
    returnResult - Return value from WMI for starting the process (not the exit value of the process).
    processID - The process id of the remote process.
    processReturnCode - The return code of the remote process.
    stdOut - Standard output from the remote process.
    stdErr - Standard error from the remote process.

Notes\: 
List of possible encoding names (Support for the encoding may depend on the version or language of the RAS OS)\:

5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.631776cb-bb4e-41ca-8b99-81572d1766a7.prompt=Enter a value for apiHostUser 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.720c7020-84f5-45f9-98f9-39f062f09111.prompt=Enter a value for apiHostUser 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.7f3e6c81-fce9-47d5-a479-9359bf9d9810.prompt=Enter a value for apiHostPassword 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.8326732c-e499-4bd4-8445-ca39e08c1f72.prompt=Enter a value for roleName 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.8ff99905-8504-4c30-acd2-1aff40b03e03.prompt=Enter a value for apiHostName 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.90e938e1-ff32-43e3-af04-b0a9faa68f6d.prompt=Enter a value for apiHostRepo 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.a17cbf10-32aa-4653-8fba-da559cbe06d3.description=
Accepts an object in the JavaScript Object Notation format (JSON) and
returns a value for the specified key.

The JSON format encodes objects as a set of unordered key/value pairs, which is
similar to a structure or map in other programming languages.  For example,
   { "city" \: "Palo Alto", 
     "state" \: "CA" }
is an object with two elements one with the name "city" having the value "Palo
Alto", and the other being the name "state" with the value "CA". This operation would 
return "Palo Alto" if user enters "city" as a key.

If the input object contains JSON array, array index can be used in the key input. For example, 
{ "location"\: [
      {"city"\: "Roseville", "country"\: "United States"},
      {"city"\: "Cluj", "country"\: "Romania"},
      {"city"\: "Yehud", "country"\: "Israel"}]    
}
The operation would return "Roseville" if user enters "location[0].city" as a key.

JavaScript objects are useful for representing structured data, and are
especially when used within an array.  For example, an operation that retrieves
a set of incidents from an external system may return the entire list in one
array of incident objects.  The description of the enclosing folder,
/Library/Utility Operations/Container/JavaScript Objects has more examples, and
the JSON format is described completely at http\://www.json.org.

Inputs

   object
      The JavaScript object.  
      The operation will return a failure if it is not a JavaScript object.

   key
      The key in the object to get the value of.

Responses

   success
      The value was successfully returned for the specified key. 

   failure
      There was some error in processing the object, most likely because the
      object is not in valid JavaScript Object Notation or the specified key does not exist in the object.  
      You may wish to use a tool such as http\://www.jsonlint.com/ to help diagnose problems with
      JavaScript Object Notation.

Outputs

   The primary output will be the value for the specified key in the object.

Note

    If the value in JSON object is in scientific notation, the returned output will be converted to an equivalent decimal number. Ex, 2.9e+1 will be converted to 29.
5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.a5249e29-7dc6-4db4-8786-a8dea4e299d6.prompt=Enter a value for responseTimeOut 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.a74ccd62-75ef-42b5-bd0d-64e0a2d37a2d.callout=Update Role 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.a75cffdb-d78e-4050-9e88-5de6154734e9.description=\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#Additional Parameters\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\# This operation gets the detalis of a specified role. Inputs\: roleName - The role name. responseTimeOut - Time out for the operation, populates the OOB timeout variable. apiHostName - The name/fqdn of a host which runs Chefs APi client (knife). apiHostUser - A user name with sufficient rights to run the knife commands. apiHostPassword - The apiHostUser's password. apiHostRepo - The path to the chef repository (The chef-repo folder). outputFormat - The format of the result. You can use json\text\yaml\pp \#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#Original Description\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\# 
Uses WMI to attempt to create a remote process on a machine.  The command passed should be formatted as though it was run on the command line.

CAUTION\: internally 'cmd /c' gets prepended to the command passed.  Also '2>tempfile 1>tempfile' get appended to the command so that we can attempt to capture stdout and stderr.
So your command will look like this when executed\:
	'cmd /c [yourcommand] 2>temperr 1>tempout'

Inputs\:
    host - Hostname or ip address of the target machine.
    command - The command you want executed. Special characters\: <, >, (, ), & need to be escaped using the caret (^) character.  The only exception to this rule is when the > character is used to redirect output.
    user - Username to use for remote WMI impersonation and thread impersonation on the RAS host for this operation (can be left blank).
    password - Password of the user.
    outputPath - Network accessible path used by the operation to store temporary files. If not specified it points to \\host\admin$\temp\'. If this path is not accessible you should change it to use another share that the host local system account has write access to. By default the path will have to be changed on Windows 2000 systems.
    currentDirectory - Current directory.
    characterSet - The character encoding used to write the batch file that will be remotely executed by the operation. Unicode character encodings may not supported for this input (utf-8, utf-16, etc.).  Support for unicode encodings depends on target system capabilities.  By default this encoding will also be used to read the command output that is redirected to temporary files.  If the command output is expected to be of different encoding, specify the different encoding in the outputCharacterSet input.  Default value\: The encoding of the operating system where is RAS installed.
Examples\: ibm437, shift_jis
    outputCharacterSet - The character encoding used to read the command output that was redirected to temporary files.  Only need to specify this input if the output of the command is known to output a different character encoding.  As an example\: the 'wmic' command returns utf-16 encoded output.
Examples\: ibm437, shift_jis, utf-8, utf-16
    timeout - The number of seconds before assuming the remote process is no longer functional. After the timeout has expired the remote process and all child processes will be terminated.
Default value\: 90

Responses\:
    success - Remote process successfully launched and has completed executing.
    failure - Unable to start remote process.

Results\:
    returnResult - Return value from WMI for starting the process (not the exit value of the process).
    processID - The process id of the remote process.
    processReturnCode - The return code of the remote process.
    stdOut - Standard output from the remote process.
    stdErr - Standard error from the remote process.

Notes\: 
List of possible encoding names (Support for the encoding may depend on the version or language of the RAS OS)\:

Encoding Name\:	Description\:
IBM437		OEM United States
DOS-720		Arabic (DOS)
ibm737		Greek (DOS)
ibm775		Baltic (DOS)
ibm850		Western European (DOS)
ibm852		Central European (DOS)
IBM855		OEM Cyrillic
ibm857		Turkish (DOS)
IBM00858		OEM Multilingual Latin I
IBM860		Portuguese (DOS)
ibm861		Icelandic (DOS)
DOS-862		Hebrew (DOS)
IBM863		French Canadian (DOS)
IBM864		Arabic (864)
IBM865		Nordic (DOS)
cp866		Cyrillic (DOS)
ibm869		Greek, Modern (DOS)
shift_jis		Japanese (Shift-JIS)
gb2312		Chinese Simplified (GB2312)
ks_c_5601-1987	Korean
big5		Chinese Traditional (Big5)
utf-16		Unicode
unicodeFFFE		Unicode (Big-Endian)
utf-7		Unicode (UTF-7)
utf-8		Unicode (UTF-8)
utf-32		Unicode (UTF-32)
utf-32BE		Unicode (UTF-32 Big-Endian)
Johab		Korean (Johab)
us-ascii		US-ASCII
koi8-r		Cyrillic (KOI8-R)
euc-jp		Japanese (EUC)
EUC-CN		Chinese Simplified (EUC)
euc-kr		Korean (EUC)
hz-gb-2312		Chinese Simplified (HZ)
GB18030		Chinese Simplified (GB18030)
5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.a87301c9-ab74-49aa-80a7-c5b71bbc9fe1.description=
This is an operation that does nothing. It can be used for filtering flow variables by feeding them in as inputs and filtering them on the results tab.

Inputs\:
field1 - optional input that can be used for filtering flow variables.
field2 - optional input that can be used for filtering flow variables.
field3 - optional input that can be used for filtering flow variables.
field4 - optional input that can be used for filtering flow variables.

Responses\:
success - this operation never fails.
5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.a8de3483-ad89-4c4b-be8c-8ef84a8fd3c6.prompt=Enter a value for apiHostName 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.a96f0fdc-f4b0-4420-8033-7c01dd5bd76c.description=
Insert an object into a JSON array, optionally specifying the position at which to insert the new object. 

This Operation differes from the 'Add to Array' operation in that this one will try and validate the new element as
a JSON object, whereas 'Add to Array' will just wrap the element in quotes and treat it as a string. This means 
that the element passed into this operation must be a valid JSON object, or the operation will fail. 

When specifying the index to an array element in javascript it is possible to use the standard notation, where the 1st 
element from the left is index 0, and the right-most element is (n-1), in an array with n elements. However, 
it is also possible to specify elements starting from the right side of the array using negative numbers, in which case
the right-most element is referred to by index -1 and the left-most element is at position (-1 * n), again for an array with n elements.

Inputs\:
    array - String representation of a JSON array. Arrays in JSON are comma seperated lists of objects, enclosed in square brackets ( [ ] ).
Examples\: [1,2,3] or ["one","two","three"] or [{"one"\:1, "two"\:2}, 3, "four"]

    element - The element to insert into the array. As noted above, this must be a valid JSON object or the operation will fail. It can be 
                    any valid JSON object; such as a number, string, an array, or a name/value pair list. Numbers can be entered as-is, strings
                    must be wrapped in quotes, and objects must be formated correctly (see examples below for more info)
Valid values\: Any valid JSON object
Examples\: 1 or "a string" or {"one"\:"two", "three"\:"four"} or [1,2,3]

    index -The index in the array at which to insert the new element. If index is undefined, or index is equal to the length of the array 
               (one past the last element), the new element is placed at the end of the array. See the notes above for more information
               on using negative numbers to specify array elements.
               If the index is valid, the new element is inserted at that position, and all remaining elements are shifted one position to the right.

Valid values\: Integer between (-1*n) and (n-1) for an array with n elements.
Default value\: undefined (insert the new element at the end of the array)


Responses\:
    success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
    failure - The operation failed. See the message in returnResult for details


Results\:
    returnResult - The new JSON array with the inserted element.
5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.ae99d7b7-f187-4c18-a26d-734169a59a2c.callout=Create a new json file for the role 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.b2ed71d1-6953-4ac9-9c8a-ce73508c2afd.prompt=apiHostUser's password 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.b4d7b51c-e36a-4a05-8249-1b7a24a6d354.prompt=Enter a value for apiHostRepo 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.b5740f1f-0102-4146-9204-55def73962ad.prompt=Enter a value for apiHostRepo 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.bde71599-ad09-4519-bd4c-4a7fa9aacc02.prompt=Enter a value for apiHostName 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.be179a29-f279-4290-bd32-ab7aa38e578e.description=
This is an operation that does nothing. It can be used for filtering flow variables by feeding them in as inputs and filtering them on the results tab.

Inputs\:
field1 - optional input that can be used for filtering flow variables.
field2 - optional input that can be used for filtering flow variables.
field3 - optional input that can be used for filtering flow variables.
field4 - optional input that can be used for filtering flow variables.

Responses\:
success - this operation never fails.
5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.c0580ece-2169-4bb1-b048-e6b45bb946ef.prompt=Enter a value for apiHostName 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.c570607d-94b5-4ca0-ba78-bf277549fa53.prompt=Enter a value for responseTimeOut 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.cb29236c-bb54-498d-888a-4366e2c629f4.callout=In case the default recipe should be added, the cookbookname should be used as the run list item 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.cb3b9b6d-1ffe-45c9-8053-75cc71e90287.description=
Compares two strings, returning a true response if and only if they contain the same sequence of characters. A null string is considered to be equal to an empty string.

Inputs\:
string1 - The first string.
string2 - The second string.
ignoreCase - If set to 'true', then the comparison ignores case considerations. The two strings are considered equal ignoring case if they are of the same length and corresponding characters in the two strings are equal ignoring case. If set to any value other than 'true', then the strings must match exactly to be considered equal.

responses\:
true - If the two strings are equal
false - If the two strings are not equal
5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.d4a35b9a-d37a-4de7-87bd-c40a14c4358c.description=List a cookbook's recipes. Inputs\: cookbookName - The cookbook name. responseTimeOut - Time out (in seconds) for the operations. apiHostName - The name/fqdn of a host which runs Chefs APi client (knife). apiHostUser - A user name with sufficient rights to run the knife commands. apiHostPassword - The apiHostUser's password. apiHostRepo - The path to the chef repository (The chef-repo folder). Outputs\: recipeList - The list of recipes in the cookbook. 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.d64ba7a7-7668-4981-913e-c5b4f98cd518.description=
Adds a flow variable into the local context (available to itself and child flows only)

Input Parameters\:
keyName - the name of the flow variable to use
myValue - the value to assign the flow variable

Responses\:
success - assigned the flow variable

Scriptlet Example\:
[$scriptletContext putGlobal\: $keyName, $myValue];
5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.d8240ab1-5620-4935-a610-4627c9778980.callout=Please Note\: The operations assune that the file is located under chef-repo and that the file name is the role namewith the "json" extention 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.d98a15db-9276-4942-ac1c-047123a23f4a.prompt=The name/fqdn of a host which runs Chefs APi client (knife). 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.d9cebc91-39e3-42aa-be40-9ae7b5b93649.prompt=Enter a value for responseTimeOut 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.dc2dc065-1208-4b00-bd31-149ec355bc02.callout=Get Role 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.dcacef82-e825-47e8-8eb2-0b77914dd3e2.prompt=Enter a value for apiHostUser 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.description=
Add a selected recipe to a selected role.
This flow prepares a role json file in order to update the role, by using the "knife role from file" command.

Inputs\:
filePath - The path to the role file location ( ....\chef-repo\roles)
responseTimeOut - Time out (in seconds) for the operations.
apiHostName - The name/fqdn of a host which runs Chefs APi client (knife).
apiHostUser - A user name with sufficient rights to run the knife commands.
apiHostPassword - The apiHostUser's password.
apiHostRepo - The path to the chef repository (The chef-repo folder).


Notes\:
- The operations assumes that the file is located under chef-repo\roles and that the file name is the role's name with the "json" extension.
5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.f01cd8f0-ee4d-4cdc-85ef-3d7c00222ea3.prompt=The time out for the operations (in seconds). 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.f2c94c26-30a7-475d-a770-7c67e1af12d2.prompt=Enter a value for apiHostPassword 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.f5e8b299-d8b4-465d-bda9-f6cb1b0b0f77.prompt=The path to the role file location ( ....\chef-repo\roles) 5de842ad-bef4-4ef4-a022-1c1a795f7198.fcad63e5-08c4-49d1-a35c-aa27bbb69f4d.callout=This Flow deploys a cookbook from the community on the server and then deploys a recipe from the cookbook on one or more selected nodes
flow.name: Add Recipe to Role

step.name: Create or Update Role from File
